{{About|the Tsubasa: Reservoir Chronicle protagonist|other uses|Syaoran (disambiguation){{!}}Syaoran}} {{good article}} {{DISPLAYTITLE:Syaoran (''Tsubasa: Reservoir Chronicle'')}} {{Infobox animanga character | name = Syaoran | series = [[Tsubasa: Reservoir Chronicle]]
[[xxxHolic]] |image = [[File:SyaoranTsubasa.jpg]] | caption = Syaoran as seen in ''Tsubasa: Reservoir Chronicle'' | first = ''Tsubasa: Reservoir Chronicle'' chapter 1
''xxxHolic'' chapter 8 | creator = [[Clamp (manga artists)|Clamp]] | voiced by = [[Miyu Irino]] (Japanese)
[[Jason Liebrecht]] (English) }} {{nihongo|'''Syaoran'''|小狼|Shaoran}} is a [[Character (arts)|fictional character]] and [[protagonist]] in ''[[Tsubasa: Reservoir Chronicle]]'', a [[manga]] series written and illustrated by [[Clamp (manga artists)|Clamp]]. Syaoran is introduced as a young archaeologist who is in love with [[Sakura (Tsubasa: Reservoir Chronicle)|Sakura]], his childhood friend and the princess from the Kingdom of Clow. When Sakura's memories are scattered throughout [[Parallel universe (fiction)|parallel dimensions]], Syaoran goes on a quest to recover them, at the cost of Sakura never remembering him. Later in the series, Syaoran is revealed to be a clone created by [[List of Tsubasa: Reservoir Chronicle characters#Fei-Wang Reed|Fei-Wang Reed]]{{mdash}}the sorcerer who caused Sakura to lose her memories. As a seal from [[List of Tsubasa: Reservoir Chronicle characters#Tsubasa (Syaoran)|his original self]] placed on the clone's body breaks, Syaoran becomes one of the series' [[antagonist]]s, moving according to Fei-Wang's will. Syaoran has featured in other works by Clamp, including the manga ''[[xxxHolic]]'' and the [[drama CD]] series ''Holistuba''. Syaoran's character is based on [[Syaoran Li]], a character from Clamp's ''[[Cardcaptor Sakura]]'' manga and had several changes to appeal to the series' demographic. The character has been well received by readers of the series, placing high in popularity polls from ''Tsubasa'' and manga and anime series in general. He also received positive comments by manga and anime publications. Syaoran's role as an antagonist has also received positive comments; some writers use nicknames to differentiate his antagonistic self from his original self, often calling him evil. ==Appearances== ===In ''Tsubasa: Reservoir Chronicle''=== Syaoran is introduced in ''Tsubasa: Reservoir Chronicle'' as a young archaeologist who often visits the Kingdom of Clow and is in love with his childhood friend Sakura, the kingdom's princess.{{cite book |title=Tsubasa: Reservoir Chronicle, Volume 1 |year= 2004|author=Clamp |publisher= [[Del Rey Manga]] |chapter=Chapitre 1|isbn= 978-0-345-47057-7 }} Syaoran is the adopted son of the late archeologist [[List of Tsubasa: Reservoir Chronicle characters#Fujitaka|Fujitaka]], who found him as a child in the street with no memories of his past.{{cite book |title=Tsubasa: Reservoir Chronicle, Volume 4 |year= 2005|author=Clamp |publisher= [[Del Rey Manga]] |chapter=Chapitre 22|isbn= 978-0-345-47791-0 }} Syaoran often accompanied his father on expeditions, and following his father's death, he lived alone while continuing his father's job. After Sakura's memories are scattered in the form of feathers throughout many dimensions, Syaoran meets [[Yūko Ichihara]], a witch who gives him, [[Fai D. Flowright]], and [[Kurogane (Tsubasa: Reservoir Chronicle)|Kurogane]]{{mdash}}her other clients{{mdash}}[[Mokona Modoki]]; a creature that can transport them to different dimensions. Syaoran pays Yūko for the use of Mokona with all of Sakura's memories that involved him.{{cite book |title=Tsubasa: Reservoir Chronicle, Volume 1 |year= 2004|author=Clamp |publisher= [[Del Rey Manga]] |chapter=Chapitre 2|isbn= 978-0-345-47057-7 }}{{cite book |title=Tsubasa: Reservoir Chronicle, Volume 1 |year= 2004|author=Clamp |publisher= [[Del Rey Manga]] |chapter=Chapitre 3|isbn= 978-0-345-47057-7 }} Throughout the journey, Syaoran starts bonding with Sakura again, and becomes friends with Fai, Kurogane, and Mokona.{{cite book |title=Tsubasa: Reservoir Chronicle, Volume 12 |year= 2007|author=Clamp |publisher= [[Del Rey Manga]] |chapter=Chapitre 87|isbn= 978-0-345-48532-8}} Syaoran specializes in [[hand-to-hand combat]], mainly focusing on kicks taught by hunter [[List of Tsubasa: Reservoir Chronicle characters#Seishirō|Seishirō]] during his childhood when he had no visual perception of depth because he was blind in his right eye.{{cite book |title=Tsubasa: Reservoir Chronicle, Volume 5 |year= 2005|author=Clamp |publisher= [[Del Rey Manga]] |chapter=Chapitre 34|isbn= 978-0-345-47792-7}}{{cite book |title=Tsubasa: Reservoir Chronicle, Volume 6 |year= 2005|author=Clamp |publisher= [[Del Rey Manga]] |chapter=Chapitre 42|isbn= 978-0-345-47793-4}} He later trains blindfolded with Kurogane to overcome this weakness.{{cite book |title=Tsubasa: Reservoir Chronicle, Volume 6 |year= 2005|author=Clamp |publisher= [[Del Rey Manga]] |chapter=Chapitre 41|isbn= 978-0-345-47793-4}} Kurogane also teaches him swordsmaship to make him a stronger fighter, and he gains {{nihongo|Hien|緋炎||lit. "Scarlet Flame"}}{{mdash}}a sword with magical properties that allow it to create fire.{{cite book |title=Tsubasa: Reservoir Chronicle, Volume 6 |year= 2005|author=Clamp |publisher= [[Del Rey Manga]] |chapter=Chapitre 40|isbn= 978-0-345-47793-4}}{{cite book |title=Tsubasa: Reservoir Chronicle, Volume 7 |year= 2005|author=Clamp |publisher= [[Del Rey Manga]] |chapter=Chapitre 49|isbn= 978-0-345-47797-2}} Syaoran is a clone of [[List of Tsubasa: Reservoir Chronicle characters#Tsubasa (Syaoran)|another teenager]]; the sorcerer Fei-Wang Reed created the clone to find Sakura's feathers. The original Syaoran placed some of his "[[Heart (symbol)|heart]]" within the clone's right eye, allowing the clone to develop his own personality.{{cite book |title=Tsubasa: Reservoir Chronicle, Volume 16 |year= 2008|author=Clamp |publisher= [[Del Rey Manga]] |chapter=Chapitre 119|isbn= 978-0-345-50148-6 }} After the seal breaks, Syaoran loses all his emotions and Fei-Wang uses him to collect feathers in other dimensions on his own, betraying his friends.{{cite book |title=Tsubasa: Reservoir Chronicle, Volume 16 |year= 2008|author=Clamp |publisher= [[Del Rey Manga]] |chapter=Chapitre 124|isbn= 978-0-345-50148-6 }}{{cite book |title=Tsubasa: Reservoir Chronicle, Volume 18 |year= 2008|author=Clamp |publisher= [[Del Rey Manga]] |chapter=Chapitre 135|isbn= 978-0-345-50409-8 }} Syaoran becomes immune to pain, which makes him ruthless and strong. Before leaving his former friends, he devours Fai's left eye to gain his own magic powers, which grow stronger every time he uses them.{{cite book |title=Tsubasa: Reservoir Chronicle, Volume 16 |year= 2008|author=Clamp |publisher= [[Del Rey Manga]] |chapter=Chapitre 121|isbn= 978-0-345-50148-6 }}{{cite book |title=Tsubasa: Reservoir Chronicle, Volume 23 |year= 2009|author=Clamp |publisher= [[Del Rey Manga]] |chapter=Chapitre 175|isbn= 978-0-345-51230-7 }} When fighting his original self, Syaoran destroys Sakura's soul{{mdash}}which is revealed as another clone who asks Syaoran to recover his heart just before disappearing.{{cite book |title=Tsubasa: Reservoir Chronicle, Volume 23 |year= 2009|author=Clamp |publisher= [[Del Rey Manga]] |chapter=Chapitre 179|isbn= 978-0-345-51230-7 }} Despite being shocked by this, Syaoran is again emotionless when the original Syaoran, Kurogane and Fai go to fight Fei-Wang.{{cite book |title=Tsubasa: Reservoir Chronicle, Volume 26 |year= 2010|author=Clamp |publisher= [[Del Rey Manga]] |chapter=Chapitre 207|isbn= 978-0-345-52070-8 }} In the course of the battle, Syaoran betrays Fei-Wang to help his original self kill him. When Fei-Wang tries to kill the original Syaoran, the clone intervenes and is impaled by Fei-Wang's sword.{{cite book |title=Tsubasa: Reservoir Chronicle, Volume 26 |year= 2010|author=Clamp |publisher= [[Del Rey Manga]] |chapter=Chapitre 209|isbn= 978-0-345-52070-8 }} As his body is about to be destroyed, Syaoran apologizes to his friends{{mdash}}including the original Syaoran{{mdash}}leaving only the eye he took from Fai.{{cite book |title=Tsubasa: Reservoir Chronicle, Volume 26 |year= 2010|author=Clamp |publisher= [[Del Rey Manga]] |chapter=Chapitre 210|isbn= 978-0-345-52070-8 }}{{cite book |title=Tsubasa: Reservoir Chronicle, Volume 27 |year= 2010|author=Clamp |publisher= [[Del Rey Manga]] |chapter=Chapitre 211|isbn= 978-0-345-52071-5 }} Yūko later rebuilds Syaoran's and Sakura's bodies using the remnants left after their apparent deaths.{{cite book |title=Tsubasa: Reservoir Chronicle, Volume 27 |year= 2010|author=Clamp |publisher= [[Del Rey Manga]] |chapter=Chapitre 219|isbn= 978-0-345-52071-5 }} As neither could properly die, Yūko grants their wishes to be reborn as normal humans, which Syaoran accepts because Sakura tells him she wants to stay with him.{{cite book |title=Tsubasa: Reservoir Chronicle, Volume 28 |year= 2010|author=Clamp |publisher= [[Del Rey Manga]] |chapter=Chapitre 220|isbn= 978-0-345-52164-4}}{{cite book |title=Tsubasa: Reservoir Chronicle, Volume 28 |year= 2010|author=Clamp |publisher= [[Del Rey Manga]] |chapter=Chapitre 221|isbn= 978-0-345-52164-4}} As both grow up as normal humans, they meet and live together. He and Sakura have a son, who is the original Syaoran, creating a [[time paradox]].{{cite book |title=Tsubasa: Reservoir Chronicle, Volume 28 |year= 2010|author=Clamp |publisher= [[Del Rey Manga]] |chapter=Chapitre 223|isbn= 978-0-345-52164-4}} Because they realize that all the previous events would be repeated and their son would not be able to save the [[List of Tsubasa: Reservoir Chronicle characters#Tsubasa (Sakura)|original Sakura]], they seal themselves inside a glass tube hidden in Yūko's shop. Being reborn as a descendant of the sorcerer [[List of Tsubasa: Reservoir Chronicle characters#Clow Reed|Clow Reed]], Syaoran and Sakura break free from the tube and use their new powers to help their friends defeat Fei-Wang.{{cite book |title=Tsubasa: Reservoir Chronicle, Volume 28 |year= 2010|author=Clamp |publisher= [[Del Rey Manga]] |chapter=Chapitre 224|isbn= 978-0-345-52164-4}} As their creator dies, Syaoran and Sakura vanish, leaving two feathers that merge within their original selves' bodies.{{cite book |title=Tsubasa: Reservoir Chronicle, Volume 28 |year= 2010|author=Clamp |publisher= [[Del Rey Manga]] |chapter=Chapitre 232|isbn= 978-0-345-52164-4}}{{cite book |title=Tsubasa: Reservoir Chronicle, Volume 28 |year= 2010|author=Clamp |publisher= [[Del Rey Manga]] |chapter=Chapitre 233|isbn= 978-0-345-52164-4}} ===Other appearances=== Syaoran appears in other adaptations of ''Tsubasa'', including the animated film ''[[Tsubasa Reservoir Chronicle the Movie: The Princess in the Birdcage Kingdom]]'', in which he still travels with Sakura, Fai, Kurogane and Mokona across dimensions.{{cite AV media |date = February 2008 |title = Clamp Double Feature: Tsubasa Chronicle and xxxHOLiC|medium = [[DVD]] |publisher = Funimation Entertainment}} He is included a playable character in two [[Nintendo DS]] [[video game]]s from ''Tsubasa''.{{cite web | title=Tsubasa Chronicle to DS|date=May 23, 2005|author=Gantayat, Anoop| publisher=IGN | url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2005/05/23/tsubasa-chronicle-to-ds| accessdate=November 5, 2010}} In the drama CD series ''The Matinée of the Palace'', Syaoran's group perform a play that re-enacts the series' story while searching for one of Sakura's feathers.{{cite AV media notes |trans-title="The Matinée of the Palace" Chapter.1 ~Coral, the City on the Water~|title=「王宮のマチネ」Chapter.1 ~ありえないゴール~|titlelink= |others=Clamp|year=2005|publisher=Victor Entertainment|id=VICL-61794}} Outside ''Tsubasa'', Syaoran appears in Clamp's manga ''[[xxxHolic]]'', which shows events in ''Tsubasa: Reservoir Chronicle''.{{cite book |title= xxxHolic, Volume 1 |year= 2004|author=Clamp |publisher= [[Del Rey Manga]] |chapter=Chapter 8|isbn= 978-0-345-47058-4}} He does not appear in the animated adaptions of ''xxxHolic'' until the [[original video animation]] (OVA) series ''xxxHolic Shunmuki'', in which he appears in the Dream World to confront the original Syaoran.{{cite AV media|date=June 2009|title=xxxHolic Shunmuki, Last Part|type=[[DVD]]|publisher=Kodansha}} In the spin-off drama CD series ''Holitsuba Gakuen'', Syaoran is featured as a new student in a school named "Holitsuba", which includes characters from ''Tsubasa'' and ''xxxHolic''. While he shares traits with his ''Tsubasa'' persona, such as his relationship with Sakura, he is portrayed as the identical twin of the original Syaoran.{{cite AV media notes |trans-title=Private High School Holitsuba' Episode 2: Heartpounding Preparation for the Holitsuba festival!|title=「私立堀鐔学園」第2話･堀鐔祭準備中にドッキドキ! |titlelink= |others=Clamp|year=2006|publisher=Kodansha|id=}} ==Creation and conception== Clamp designed Syaoran using the ideas of manga author [[Osamu Tezuka]] and his [[Osamu Tezuka's Star System|Star System]].{{cite book |last=Fujie |first=Kazuhisa |authorlink=Kazuhisa Fujie |author2=[[LABAAMEN]] |title=Tsubasa Chronicle Factbook: Mystery, Magic & Mischief |publisher=[[DH Publishing]] |year=2008 |page=10 |isbn=978-1-932897-26-5}} Syaoran was based on [[Syaoran Li]], a character from ''[[Cardcaptor Sakura]]''{{mdash}}another series written by Clamp. Syaoran and Sakura were chosen to be the series' protagonist because their ''Cardcaptor Sakura'' counterparts had a happy ending, but Clamp said that the characters would have to go throughout the series to get their own happy ending. At the start of the manga, Syaoran's character was already planned to go through development. The characters [[Fai D. Flowright]] and [[Kurogane (Tsubasa: Reservoir Chronicle)|Kurogane]] were added to provide additional characters who were older than Syaoran.{{cite web|title=Anime Expo 15 Cosplay 2006 |publisher=John (Phoenix) Brown |date=January 11, 2009 |url=http://www.phoenixanime.com/ax06/page5.htm |accessdate=April 21, 2009 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5unxRgAvf?url=http://www.phoenixanime.com/ax06/page5.htm |archivedate=December 7, 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }} In early versions of the manga, Syaoran was portrayed as a mechanic rather than an archaeologist, with Fujitaka having taught him about machines. In the original design, Syaoran wore a cap, a different outfit and an enormous [[adjustable spanner]].{{cite book |last=Clamp |authorlink=Clamp (manga artists) |others=translated and adapted by William Flanagan |title=Tsubasa CHARACTer GuiDE |publisher=[[Del Rey Manga]] |year=2005 |location=[[New York City|New York]] |page=205|isbn=978-4-06-372001-3}} Clamp said Syaoran became popular with male readers as a hero. After events of the Oto country where Syaoran participated in several battles fighting for the king Ashura and was at disadvantage, Clamp's editor for ''Tsubasa'', Kiichiro Sugawara, wrote that he wondered whether "anything good ever happen[s] to Syaoran"; Clamp said that their publishing company, [[Kodansha]] had received demands from readers for Syaoran to become stronger, and advised Clamp to let him have occasional good experiences.{{cite book |last=Clamp |authorlink=Clamp (manga artists) |others=Translated and adapted by [[Tokyopop]] |title=CLAMP no Kiseki Vol. 11 |publisher=Tokyopop |year=2005 |location=[[Los Angeles]] |page=5 |isbn=978-1-59532-615-7}} In order to make his fight scenes more entertaining, Clamp thought about giving Syaoran named sword techniques like those of Kurogane but in the end this was not added to the series.{{cite book |last=Clamp |authorlink=Clamp (manga artists) |others=Translated and adapted by [[Tokyopop]] |title=CLAMP no Kiseki Vol. 12 |publisher=Tokyopop |year=2005 |location=[[Los Angeles]] |pages=5–7 |isbn=978-1-59532-616-4}} Clamp originally planned Subaru to be Syaoran's teacher. However, the group later decided to replace Subaru with Seishiro. During the second half of the manga when it was revealed Syaoran was a clone from another character who became the protagonist. Clamp aimed to make both of them equally different based on their actions despite being virtually identical.{{cite book |last=Clamp |authorlink=Clamp (manga artists) |title=公式ガイドブック ツバサ CARACTere CHRoNiCLE |publisher=[[Kodansha]] |year=2016|isbn=978-4063931280}} In the animated adaptations of ''Tsubasa: Reservoir Chronicle'', Syaoran is voiced by [[Miyu Irino]] in Japanese, and by [[Jason Liebrecht]] in English.{{cite web|title=STAFF & CAST |url=http://www.productionig.com/contents/works_sp/21_/s03_/index.html |publisher=Production I.G |accessdate=November 22, 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5uQvUaJHL?url=http://www.productionig.com/contents/works_sp/21_/s03_/index.html |archivedate=November 22, 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }}{{cite web |title=Tsubasa English Cast Announced|publisher=Anime News Network|date=February 25, 2007 |url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2007-02-25/tsubasa-english-cast-announced|accessdate=November 26, 2010}} Irino said that ever since the introduction of the original Syaoran{{mdash}}who he also voiced{{mdash}}he sometimes had problems voicing both characters. Fellow voice actress [[Yui Makino]] also discussed Irino's role, saying that he was the most difficult character to cast because of the requirement to portray the two Syaorans.{{cite web |title=舞台は日本国！ 「ツバサ」アニメ企画に向け監督＆キャスト陣にインタビュー|trans-title=The stage is Japan! Tsubasa, Planning for the new animation and interviews with cast member|publisher=[[ASCII Media Works]]|date=October 30, 2010|url=http://news.dengeki.com/elem/000/000/117/117012/|accessdate=February 13, 2011}} ==Reception== Syaoran was well received by Japanese readers of ''Tsubasa: Reservoir Chronicle''. In two popularity polls held by ''[[Weekly Shōnen Magazine]]'', Syaoran was the most-liked character. He was also highly rated in other polls, which included best groups and best scenes from the series.{{cite book |last=Clamp |authorlink=Clamp (manga artists) |others=translated and adapted by William Flanagan|title=Tsubasa CHARACTer GuiDE |publisher=[[Del Rey Manga]] |year=2005 |location=[[New York City|New York]] |pages=148–152 |isbn=978-4-06-372001-3}}{{cite book |last=Clamp |authorlink=Clamp (manga artists) |others=translated and adapted by William Flanagan|title=Tsubasa CHARACTer GuiDE 2|publisher=[[Del Rey Manga]] |year=2006 |location=[[New York City|New York]] |pages=144–148 |isbn=978-4-06-372216-1}} In March 2010, Syaoran was ranked twenty-third best male anime character of the 2000s by the Japanese magazine ''[[Newtype]]''.{{cite journal | journal=[[Newtype]] | publisher=[[Kadokawa Shoten]] | title=Newtype's Top 30 Male and Female Characters of Each Decade | date=March 2010 | language=Japanese}} In the ''[[Animage]]''{{'}}s [[Anime Grand Prix]] poll from 2006, he was voted as the twelfth most popular male anime character.{{cite web|script-title=ja:第28回アニメグランプリ　［2006年6月号］（現在位置） |trans-title=28th Anime Grand Prix June 2006 issue (current position) |url=http://animage.jp/gp_new/gpx_2006.html |publisher=Animage |language=Japanese |accessdate=January 26, 2011 |date=June 2006 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6RYonFvqr?url=http://animage.jp/gp_new/gpx_2006.html |archivedate=August 3, 2014 |df= }} In the same year, he remained the fourteenth most popular male character.{{cite journal | journal=[[Animage]] | publisher=[[Gakken]] | title=Anime Grand Prix 2006–2007| date=May 2007 | language=Japanese}} In the ''Animedia'' "2006 Animedia Character Awards", Syaoran was nominated in categories including "Strongest Character Award", "Best Newcomer Award", "Most Heroic Character Award" and "MVP (Most Valuable Player) Award"; his highest rating was in the "Best Newcomer Award", where he was ranked third.{{cite journal | journal=Animedia | publisher=[[Gakken]] | title=2006 Animedia Character Awards| date=February 2010 | language=Japanese}} Various types of merchandising have been made based on Syaoran's appearance including plush, keychains and patches.{{cite web|title=Tsubasa: Syaoran Plush|publisher=[[Amazon.com]] |url=https://www.amazon.com/dp/B000TVUFXM/|accessdate=November 26, 2010}}{{cite web|title=Tsubasa Syaoran PVC Key Chain|publisher=[[Amazon.com]] |url=https://www.amazon.com/dp/B000P8J8NW/|accessdate=January 27, 2011}}{{cite web|title=GE Animation Tsubasa Syaoran GE|publisher=[[Amazon.com]] |url=https://www.amazon.com/dp/B003ZT3L72/|accessdate=January 27, 2011}} In the 2007 [[Seiyu Awards]], [[Miyu Irino]] was a nominee in the category "Best New Actor" for his portrayal as Syaoran, but lost to [[Tetsuya Kakihara]] and [[Masakazu Morita]].{{cite web |script-title=ja:アキバ総研（秋葉原総合研究所）担当者コラム番外編　声優版アカデミー賞「第1回声優アワード」|url=http://akiba.kakaku.com/hobby/0703/04/044038.php|publisher=Akiba Kakabu |accessdate=April 4, 2011|language=Japanese |date=March 4, 2007}}{{cite web |title=Results of Japan's First Ever Seiyuu Awards Announced|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2007-03-05/results-of-japan's-first-ever-seiyuu-awards-announced|publisher=[[Anime News Network]] |accessdate=April 4, 2011 |date=March 5, 2007}} Publications for manga, anime and other media have commented on Syaoran's character and role in the series. He received mainly positive responses. Ed Sizemore from Comics Worth Reading called him as "the perfect young hero" because of his seriousness, with points given for his care for Sakura.{{cite web|last=Sizemore |first=Ed |authorlink=Ed Sizemore |title=Tsubasa Reservoir Chronicles Books 1-20 and Character Guide |publisher=Comics Worth Reading |date=March 17, 2009 |url=http://comicsworthreading.com/2009/03/17/tsubasa-reservoir-chronicles-books-1-20-and-character-guide/ |accessdate=April 19, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140328064438/http://comicsworthreading.com/2009/03/17/tsubasa-reservoir-chronicles-books-1-20-and-character-guide/ |archivedate=March 28, 2014 |df= }} Although Carl Kimlinger found differences between Syaoran and his ''Cardcaptor Sakura'' counterpart, he found the traits of the former appealing.{{cite web |last=Kimlinger |first=Carl |authorlink=Carl Kimlinger |title=Tsubasa: RESERVoir CHRoNiCLE DVD 4+5 |publisher=[[Anime News Network]] |date=January 18, 2008 |url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/review/tsubasa-reservoir-chronicle/dvd-4 |accessdate=April 19, 2009}} Michael Aronson from Manga Life found that while the characters behaves differently from Syaoran Li and act considerably older, it helps readers who have not read previous Clamp series understand the series.{{Cite web|last=Aronson |first=Michael |title=Tsubasa v1 |publisher=Manga Life |url=http://www.mangalife.com/reviews/Tsubasav1.htm |accessdate=January 27, 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071012140624/http://www.mangalife.com/reviews/Tsubasav1.htm |archivedate=October 12, 2007 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Japanese singer [[Maaya Sakamoto]] said that in the animated adaptation of ''Tsubasa: Reservoir Chronicle'', Syaoran's straightforward feelings and strength to protect Sakura were very touching. Therefore, in the song "Kazemachi Jet"{{mdash}}the closing theme of the second season of the anime{{mdash}}she tried to capture the image of Syaoran growing from his naïve self into a young man through the meetings and partings over his journey and Syaoran's continuing protection of his loved one in spite of adversity.{{cite web|title=Interview: Sakamoto Maaya outlook on Tsubasa Chronicle's world in "Kazemachi Jet / Spica" |publisher=[[Oricon]] |language=Japanese |url=http://www.oricon.co.jp/anime/topics/060607/060607_02.html |accessdate=May 14, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071031062719/http://www.oricon.co.jp/anime/topics/060607/060607_02.html |archivedate=October 31, 2007 |deadurl=yes |df= }} When writing "Saigo no Kajitsu", Sakamoto described Syaoran's fate as sad because he becomes the antagonist of his friends and is a clone.{{cite web|author=bear |title=Maaya Sakamoto Saigo no Kajitsu long interview in PALIKA |publisher=YKFan |date=2007-11-26 |url=http://bbs.ykfan.cn/viewthread.php?action=printable&tid=3861 |language=Japanese |accessdate=2009-05-15 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5w2NvKgmy?url=http://bbs.ykfan.cn/viewthread.php?action=printable&tid=3861 |archivedate=January 27, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Singer [[Kinya Kotani]] also described sadness in Syaoran's strength, and said he had both forwarding-facing and backward-facing characteristics.{{cite web|title=Periodical: Artist Interview "Anime Song Correspondence Vol.9" Kinya |publisher=[[Frontier Works]] |language=Japanese |url=http://www.animate.tv/column/singer/060601.php |accessdate=2009-05-15 |archivedate=April 1, 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080401030928/http://www.animate.tv/column/singer/060601.php |deadurl=yes |df= }} The plot twist in which Syaoran is revealed to be a clone and his fight against his original self has been regarded as "a titanic clash" by Chris Zimmerman from Comic Book Bin. Following this, Syaoran was called "evil Syaoran" and "Syaoran's evil clone".{{cite web |last=Zimmerman |first=Chris |title=Tsubasa: RESERVoir CHRoNiCLE OVA Collection Blu-ray |publisher=Comic Book Bin |date=January 16, 2011|url=http://www.comicbookbin.com/Tsubasa_Reservoir_Chronicle462.html|accessdate=January 25, 2011}}{{cite web |last=Douglass Jr. |first=Todd |title=Tsubasa: RESERVoir CHRoNiCLE - OVA Collection|publisher=DVDTalk |date=January 4, 2011|url=http://www.dvdtalk.com/reviews/46754/tsubasa-reservoir-chronicle-ova-collection/|accessdate=January 26, 2011}} The twist has been a "potential real upset" because Syaoran is revealed to have been created by the series' main antagonist, Fei-Wang Reed.{{cite web|last=Beveridge|first=Chris|title=Tsubasa, RESERVoir CHRoNiCLE OVA Collection|publisher=Mania Entertainment|date=January 3, 2011|url=http://www.mania.com/tsubasa-reservoir-chronicle-ova-collection_article_125817.html|accessdate=January 19, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/69z8DKGAd?url=http://www.mania.com/tsubasa-reservoir-chronicle-ova-collection_article_125817.html|archivedate=August 17, 2012|df=}} The relationship between both Syaorans has also been found confusing for some readers to understand;{{cite web |last=Santos |first=Carlo |authorlink=Carlo Santos |title=Tsubasa, RESERVoir CHRoNiCLE GN 16 |publisher=[[Anime News Network]] |date=March 8, 2008 |url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/review/tsubasa-reservoir-chronicle/gn-16 |accessdate=April 19, 2009}} others said that while there was confusion in this scene, the events led to a well-executed ending. They also highlighted the bond both have through their eyes. Sakura Eries from Mania Entertainment said Syaoran's actions after the twist were disturbing because of his violent acts. Syaoran has been labeled as "an agent of destruction" because he ignores seemingly mortal wounds and encounters various opponents in a single manga volume.{{cite web|last=Eries|first=Sakura|title=Tsubasa Vol. #16|publisher=Mania Entertainment|date=April 28, 2008|url=http://www.mania.com/tsubasa-vol-16_article_83523.html|accessdate=January 25, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121014092040/http://www.mania.com/tsubasa-vol-16_article_83523.html|archivedate=October 14, 2012|df=}} Eries said that she felt cheated after the revelations of Syaoran's and Sakura's true natures because it changed the readers' views of them.{{cite web|last=Eries |first=Sakura |title=Tsubasa Vol. #23 |publisher=Mania Entertainment |date=December 24, 2009 |url=http://www.mania.com/tsubasa-vol-23_article_118141.html |accessdate=January 27, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6XTT1W0Dd?url=http://www.mania.com/tsubasa-vol-23_article_118141.html |archivedate=April 1, 2015 |df= }} Mania Entertainment's Megan Lavey said Syaoran's and Sakura's initial relationship is a "pretty simple love story", and liked their personalities.{{cite web|last=Lavey |first=Megan |title=Tsubasa Vol. #01 |publisher=Mania Entertainment |date=June 23, 2004 |url=http://www.mania.com/tsubasa-vol-01_article_81618.html |accessdate=November 4, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6XTStYf4e?url=http://www.mania.com/tsubasa-vol-01_article_81618.html |archivedate=April 1, 2015 |df= }} [[IGN]]'s Jeff Harris said Syaoran's role is interesting because he sacrifices his relationship with Sakura and his own life to recover her memories.{{cite web |last=Harris |first=Jeff |title=Tsubasa: RESERVoir CHRoNiCLE, Volume 3 - Spectres of a Legend |publisher=IGN |date=October 2, 2007 |url=http://dvd.ign.com/articles/824/824397p1.html|accessdate=November 24, 2009}} Active Anime's Christopher Seaman said the romantic relationship between them is one of the most mature parts of the series, and it helped balance the other fantastic themes, which added more variety for the series' audience.{{Cite web |last=Seaman |first=Christopher |url=http://activeanime.com/html/2007/05/20/tsubasa-reservoir-chronicle-starter-set-advance-review/ |title=TSUBASA RESERVOIR CHRONICLE STARTER SET (ADVANCE REVIEW) |publisher=Active Anime |date=May 22, 2007 |accessdate=November 1, 2010 }} Kimlinger said their relationship made up for some problems in the anime adaptation. Kimlinger also said [[Jason Liebrecht]]'s role as Syaoran's English voice is better than Irino's work. However, Kimlinger praised both performances because of the way Syaoran's emotions are played.{{cite web |last=Kimlinger |first=Carl |authorlink=Carl Kimlinger |title=Tsubasa: RESERVoir CHRoNiCLE DVD 1 |publisher=[[Anime News Network]] |date=June 10, 2007 |url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/review/tsubasa-reservoir-chronicle/dvd-1 |accessdate=April 19, 2009}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} {{Tsubasa: Reservoir Chronicle}} [[Category:Anime and manga characters who use magic]] [[Category:Anime and manga martial artists]] [[Category:Clamp characters]] [[Category:Comics characters introduced in 2003]] [[Category:Fictional archaeologists]] [[Category:Fictional clones]] [[Category:Male characters in anime and manga]]

{{more citations needed|date=February 2016}} '''Thomas Taylor''' (26 February 1858 – 5 July 1938) was an English priest, historian and scholar of [[Celt]]ic culture.
==Life and career== Taylor was born in [[Thurvaston]], [[Derbyshire]], [[England]]. He attended [[King's School, Macclesfield|King Edward VI School]], [[Macclesfield]] becoming [[head boy]] in 1874. He matriculated at [[St Catharine's College, Cambridge]] in 1877, and graduated in the [[Cambridge Mathematical Tripos|Mathematics Tripos]] in 1881, receiving his [[Masters degree|MA]] in 1886.<ref>{{acad|id=TLR877T|name=Taylor, Thomas}}</ref> Taylor took Holy Orders on going down from Cambridge, being ordained [[Deacon]] at [[Rochester, Kent|Rochester]] in 1881 and was made Priest there in 1883.
After a few years (1883 – c. 1896) in Queensland, [[Australia]], he settled with his wife and family in [[Cornwall]]. He served as Vicar first at [[All Saints' Church, Falmouth]], from 1890 and then at [[Redruth]] from 1892. In 1897 he accepted the rural living of [[St Breward]].
Taylor was an honorary [[Canon (priest)|Canon]] of [[Truro Cathedral]] from 1917 to 1938. In 1919 he went to serve at [[Gunwalloe]]. He was elected Proctor and held this office from 1919 to 1935. He also served as Rural Dean of Penwith from 1924 to 1927. He became known as "the poor man’s lawyer" as a result of his freely given assistance in matters of compensation for injuries sustained in tin mining.
Canon Taylor was made a [[bard]] at the inaugural [[Gorseth Kernow]] held at [[Boscawen-Un]], [[St Buryan]] on 21 September 1928. He took the [[bardic name]] ‘'Gwas Ust'’ (‘Servant of St. Just’).
When he died in 1938, he was Vicar of St. Just. He listed his recreations as pedigree making and fly fishing.
==Scholarly work== During his time at St Breward he found the parish registers to be complete from 1599 to 1812: his work editing the registers brought him into contact with [[W. P. Phillimore]], a publisher of books relating to [[Ecclesiastical]] Law, who in 1905 appointed him editor of the [[Parish]] Marriage Registers throughout the diocese: by 1916 he had published twenty-five volumes. It is for this work, much used by genealogists and family historians, that he is probably most widely known.
He contributed to the [[Encyclopædia Britannica]] and the [[Victoria County History]] of Cornwall, of which he was local editor. His standard works ''Celtic Christianity'' and ''Life of [[St Samson of Dol]]'' are still sources of reference.
==Bibliography== *1909: ''The Life of Dr. John Taylor of Ashbourne'' Nisbet *1914: ''Cornwall Parish Registers''. Edited by Thomas Taylor. London: [[Phillimore & Co]] *1916: ''The Celtic Christianity of Cornwall'' Longmans {{ISBN|1-897853-97-1}} *1925: ''Life of St. Samson of Dol'' SPCK {{ISBN|0-947992-77-4}} *1932: ''The History of St. Michael's Mount'' [[Cambridge University Press]]
==See also== *[[Celtic Christianity]]
